duck

Embryonic stem cell research should be banned. It's a waste of time and money and it doesn't work. We should put all our money into stem cell research using only adult or umbilical cord stem cells. 
 Stem cells are cells that can develop into any organ and originally were thought to exist only in embryos. So researchers had the choice of killing a baby, or finding one that was already dead from abortion, and using their stem cells to try to cure diseases. But when a stem cell from an embryo was put into another person, the immune system would attack the stem cells thinking that they were viruses. The scientific term for this is rejection. And the cells would only grow into tumors since embryonic cells are pre-programmed to form an entire body. "The results were no successful treatments," said the National Catholic Register. 
 So why are some scientists still researching embryonic stem cells? Elenor Schoen, Communications Director for Human Life of Washington said, "They are actually exploring how the embryo's body works, not trying to find disease cures with the stem cells. Stem cell research monies give access to embryos." 
 About five or six years ago it was discovered that every human being, old or young, has stem cells in their bodies. When your own stem cells are used to treat a disease there is no rejection problem. The National Catholic Register said, "The results of adult stem cells are treatments for 56 diseases including breast cancer, and stroke." Stem cells have also been discovered in the blood of umbilical cords which are available after a birth.

Adult stem cells are different things and are used for different things - its like using a plaster cast to perform a heart bypass and then declaring that plaster casts are useless.
 Adult stem cells are only able to produce one type of cell in addition to a copy of themselves when they replicate) and can only do so a finate amount of times. Embryonic stem cells are able to replicate infinitely and can differentiate into any cell within the human body.
 
 A lot of the work and research done into embryonic stem cells is purely to see how they work - but this isn't out of curiosity, without knowing how they work there is no way you can use them safely or even use that knowledge to modify things so they behave in the same way with better focus.
 
 Really, if you know what you are trying to do then rejection is a really easy thing to get round. Thinking that treatment and research just involves sticking stem cells somewhere is drastically simplifiing things

Duck, you really need to strike at the heart of the matter.
 You're missing the mark with stem cell research.
 You can't do a thing with embryonic stem cells and you can't have those
 without an embryo and you get those from fertility clinics.
 They do one of two things with those frozen embryos.
 After a certain time, if no one has "adopted" one of the thousands 
 in each clinic, then they are destroyed.
 
 So really what you are against is in vitro fertilization.
 In the process they create about 12 embryos and then they 
 pick the most viable 2-3 to impregnate the woman with.
 Then 1 or 2 of those catch, and you get a pregnancy.
 In the process you create, destroy, and temporarily store 
 around a dozen "humans."
 http://www.conceivingconcepts.com/learning/articles/embryo.html
 
In a typical case, specialists will attempt to fertilize a dozen eggs, then implant no more than three. That leaves nine embryos, which get VIP treatment as they are stored in liquid nitrogen at minus-196 degrees Celsius, often for several years. They belong to the parents who have the option to use them again, discard them or donate them.

 They belong to the parents, who can chose to kill them if they so wish.

 Adult and umbilical stem cells are extremely difficult to work with. Embryonic stem cells multiply with easy in simple cultures allowing vast numbers to be produced, thus making them easy to work with. Over time, we may be able to overcome this and various other problems with adult stem cells. Then they will be the stem cell of choice for most treatments and research. Untill then embryonic stem cells remain vital as far as research goes.
 
 Clearly the use of embryos in stem cell research causes some upset amongst some Americans and people of some Catholic countries. Britain, and other countries, will continue to use embryos for research though regardless of what Duck and other ethical whingers. Hopefully America will win out against the ludites who oppose such research, but even if you don't you'll still get to benefit from them when other countries' scientists develop treatments for you.

 On the contrary, stem cells do lose their adaptabity over time. How much is unknown. Why is unknown. While hopefully, the ultimate source of stem cells can be unbilicord stem cells, or adult stem cells, we don't know enough about stem cells to be able to find out a number of answers. When we understand why embronic stem cells are more adaptable than the unbilicord stem cells, we might be able to return the umbilicord stem cells and the adult stem cells into the condition the embronic stem cells are in. If that can be done, then
 the umbilicord stems cells would have the advantage of not having certain ethical concerns, and they would be cheaper to get. Using stem cells from adults would have the advantage of not introducing another persons DNA 
 into the body,which might have unforeseen consequences down the road.
 
 However, we need to know more about how the cell develops. It is, after all, 
 just a cell, not a human being.
